Title: New build system and architecture for networking communication
Body: #### Description Following #439 here I'm reorganizing the repository to accommodate the new architecture. - [x] Fix #529 Build system for the new architecture - [x] Fix #566 Upgrade to Unreal Engine 4.19 - [x] Fix #555 RPC integration - [x] Fix #495 Streaming sensor data to multiple clients - [x] Fix #530 Implement first version of the new Python API and as bonus - [x] Fix #466 Embed version tag in code Once everything is done this closes #439. #### Where has this been tested? So far the new modules only compile in Linux. * **Platform(s):** Ubuntu 16.04 * **Python version(s):** 2.7 and 3.5 * **Unreal Engine version(s):** 4.19 - - - This is what's already supported ```python import random import time import carla c = carla.Client('localhost' 2000) c.set_timeout(1000) # milliseconds assert c.get_client_version() == c.get_server_version() world = c.get_world() library = world.get_blueprint_library(); # Pull a random vehicle from the library. vehicles = library.filter('vehicle'); bp = random.choice(vehicles) if bp.contains_attribute('number_of_wheels'): n = bp.get_attribute('number_of_wheels') print('got vehicle %r with %d wheels' % (bp.id n)) # You can change the color. bp.set_attribute('color' '0 0 255') # Spawn vehicle at transform. transform = carla.Transform( carla.Location(x=0.0 y=0.0 z=5.0) carla.Rotation(yaw=random.uniform(0 360))) vehicle = world.spawn_actor(bp transform) # Most of the objects are printable. print(vehicle) # You can teleport actors to a given location or transform. vehicle.set_location(carla.Location(x=180 y=199 z=38)) # You can enable/disable the old autopilot too. vehicle.set_autopilot(True) # Add a camera to the vehicle. camera_bp = bp_library.find('camera') camera_transform = carla.Transform(carla.Location(x=0.4 y=0.0 z=1.4)) camera = world.spawn_actor(camera_bp camera_transform attach_to=vehicle) # Register a lambda to be called every time we receive an image from the camera. camera.listen(lambda image: do_something_here()) try: while True: # Control the vehicle. control = carla.VehicleControl( throttle=random.uniform(0.3 1.0) steer=random.uniform(-0.1 0.1)) vehicle.apply_control(control) time.sleep(1) finally: # Destroy the actor removes it from the simulation. vehicle.destroy() ``` --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/567)

Title: New sensor system that aims to make easier adding new sensors
Body: #### Description The idea is to create a new sensor system that allows contributors to "plug in" their implementations easily. 1. Add a sensor actor. 2. Add a sensor serializer (and possibly a sensor data view in Python). 3. Register the classes. All the details below. This PR fixes: - Fixes #750 Plugin system for adding new sensors. - Fixes #687 Add Lidar to new API. - I have also removed all the legacy sensor code. **TODO:** - [x] Test that the sensor transform received is in world coordinates. - [ ] Test the resulting images on Windows and if possible with Vulkan. #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Ubuntu 16.04 * **Python version(s):** 2.7 * **Unreal Engine version(s):** 4.19 #### Possible Drawbacks I've refactored some of the code that reads the image buffers and fixed a possible bug this part is a bit tricky and should be tested in Windows to make sure everything works as expected (in Linux does) i.e. getting some images with different (odd) sizes in the client side to see they make sense. - - - ## Mini tutorial This are the steps to add a new sensor (I will add a tutorial with more detail soon): #### 1. Sensor Actor Create a sensor actor deriving from `ASensor` (or one of its derived classes) this class requires to implement the following methods: - `static FActorDefinition GetSensorDefinition();` Returns an actor definition that will be given to the user in the client-side to configure the details of the sensor. - `void Set(const FActorDescription &ActorDescription) override;` Configure the sensor with the attributes that the user requested. - `void Tick(float DeltaTime) override;` This function is called on every game update and here the sensor is expected to produce the data and send it (more on this below). - Also requires the UE4 macros `UCLASS()` and `GENERATED_BODY()`. The following sensor classes are already implemented here: `ASceneCaptureCamera` `ADepthCamera` `ASemanticSegmentationCamera` and `ARayCastLidar`. This class should be added to `Unreal/CarlaUE4/Plugins/Carla/Source/Carla/Sensor` folder. `ASensor` contains a `FDataStream` for sending the data through the streaming server. Sensor actors should write their measurements to this stream using one of the two methods in the stream `Send_Async` or `Send_GameThread` depending in which thread they're producing the data. The class `FDataStream` is quite well documented take a look for more details. The stream methods won't compile however until the sensor and its serializer are registered which takes us to the next class required. #### 2. Sensor Serializer This class is in charge of serializing and deserializing the data. The only requirement of this class is providing two static methods with the following signatures: - `static Buffer Serialize(const YourASensor &sensor ...data here...);` This function should convert the data provided by the sensor actor into a `Buffer` object. The signature is quite open. - `static SharedPtr Deserialize(RawData data);` This function has to convert a `RawData` object (which is a wrapper around a buffer with some extra meta-information) into a `SensorData` derived class. Serialization happens in the simulator-side right after writing the data to the stream. Deserialization happens in the client-side right after delivering the data to the user in the callback function provided to the `listen` method of the sensors. This class should be added to `LibCarla/source/carla/sensor/s11n` folder and its corresponding namespace. There are already some `SensorData` classes implemented like images and arrays otherwise you must add a new class fitting your needs. In this case the class must also be exposed to Python. I will add more info on this in the tutorial. #### 3. Register your classes Your classes must be registered within the `SensorRegistry` as an `std::pair`. Also follow the steps in the header as the includes must be added in the right places. ```cpp // LibCarla/source/carla/sensor/SensorRegistry.h using SensorRegistry = CompositeSerializer< std::pair std::pair std::pair std::pair >; ``` And that's it the sensor registry now do its compile-time magic to dispatch the right data to the right serializer. Well ok I might have missing something. We will be polishing this guide as we start playing around with new sensors. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/830)

Title: Add IO methods for sensor data

Title: Client side improvements
Body: #### Description Requires #829 and all its dependencies. Includes a bunch of different improvements to the client-side code: - Related to #810 C++ API has been refactored hopefully easier to use now although it still needs to be polished to be linkable to other apps but it's a step forward. - Fix #809 release GIL whenever possible (this has really improved performance of the Python API thanks @harlowja for reporting!). - Make possible to unsubscribe from a sensor (in Python sensors now have a `stop()` method). - Fix #843 Streaming client keeps trying to reconnect after destroying a sensor. - Fix #767 Deadlock when closing the simulator while a client is connected (or at least one of them). - Fix crash on simulator shutdown if a client has connected at some point. - Related to #784 vehicle control and set transform methods are now sent async which greatly improves performance in the client-side (we still want to add batch mode though). - Vehicle control is cached and not sent if haven't changed. Now it's possible to call `vehicle.apply_control(...)` continuously and the message will only be sent when necessary. Plus I redesigned the Python examples: - `example.py` is gone now there is a `tutorial.py` in which a simple example on how to use the API is commented step by step. - `manual_control.py`now has a fancy user interface (for Carla standards :wink:) and in general the driving experience should be smoother. Although you still depend on a simulator running fast the input is captured at a decent frame rate. It is also possible to change the main view between the different cameras available. #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Ubuntu 16.04 * **Python version(s):** 2.7 --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/856)

Title: A few changes for 0 9 1
Body: ## Description Massive PR with lots of changes required for 0.9.1. ###### User-side improvements - New map Town03 now set as default map. - Support for Python 3 on Linux. - Add "dynamic_weather.py" script that changes the weather in real-time. - More improvements to "manual_control.py" support for changing weather the camera view and the vehicle. - Add an option to command-line to change quality level when launching the simulator. ###### API changes - API methods for retrieving and changing weather conditions and lighting `world.get_weather()` and `world.set_weather(params)`. Add `carla.WeatherParametes` class that parametrizes the weather conditions and add weather presets to it: `carla.WeatherParametes.ClearNoon` etc. - Remove `client.ping()` `client.get_server_version()` accomplishes the same. - Add support for requesting the list of actors alive in the current world `world.get_actors()`. Returns an `ActorList` object behaves like a list but has `filter` functionality and lazy initialization of Actors. - Add id (id of current episode) and map name to `carla.World` class - Rename `contains_X()` methods to `has_X()`. - Add `semantic_tags` to Actors containing the list of tags of all of its components (these tags match the tags retrieved by the semantic segmentation sensor). - Add a "tick" message containing info of all the actors in the scene this is executed in the background and cached. This way calls to `actor.get_transform()` or `actor.get_location()` do not need to connect with the simulator but can access the cached info. This makes these calls quite cheap. - Add `world.wait_for_tick()` and `world.on_tick(callback)` methods for synchronizing the client with simulator updates. Both methods return/pass a `carla.Timestamp` object containing frame count delta time of last tick global simulation time and OS timestamp. - Add `actor.get_velocity()` and `actor.get_acceleration()` these are also cached so its quite cheap to get them. - Add bounding boxes to vehicles `vehicle.bounding_box` property. - Function to enable/disable simulating physics on an actor `actor.set_simulate_physics(enabled=True)`. - Expose traffic lights and signs as actors. Traffic lights have a specialized actor class that has the traffic light state (red green yellow) as property. - Add methods for accessing and modifying individual items in `carla.Image` (pixels) and `carla.LidarMeasurement` (locations). - Add collision event sensor "sensor.other.collision" that triggers a callback on each collision to the actor it is attached to. The callback receives a `carla.CollisionEvent` containing the actor it collided to and the normal impulse of the collision. - Add `carla.Vector3D` to generalize `carla.Location`. ###### Other C++ improvements - Add multi-streams for streaming simultaneously to multiple clients (used by the "tick" message). - Refactor of client-side code: - Add Simulator class shared by all the API objects that decides whether to call the server or retrieve a cached value. Leave `detail::Client` for pure networking operations only. - Add concept of episode to facilitate restarting episodes and changing map in the future. - Add `EpisodeProxy` that allows access to Simulator only if the episode hasn't changed. - More geom classes `geom::Vector3D` and `geom::BoundingBox`. - More synchronization classes `AtomicSharedPtr` `RecurrentSharedFuture` `CallbackList`. - Add `ActorVariant` for lazy initialization of Actors. - Add `CachedActorList` for caching Actor descriptions and reduce call to the server. - Small refactor of quality level related stuff and ported to new game mode. - Adjust camera gamma to 2.4 (by @TheNihilisticRobot). - Add MsgPack class and functions to serialize rpc objects into/from `Buffer`. - Add `AWorldObserver` sensor and its serializer for serializing all the actors registered in the episode and sending the "tick" message. - Add `ACollisionSensor` and its serializer for detecting collisions. - Add `not_spawnable` tag for sensors that cannot be spawned by the client (e.g. world observer). - Allow vehicles without color attribute to support vehicles that cannot change its color. - Archive Python eggs on Jenkins - Fine grained targets in Makefile compilation times reduced by compiling only what's necessary. - Add uncrustify config file for formatting UE4 C++ code. - Add support for ".gtest" file each line of this file is passed to GTest executables as arguments when running `make check` targets. Very handy for filtering test while developing. - Update Content assets package link which solves a lot of issues related with the assets. ###### Fixes - Fix wildcard filtering issues now "vehicle.*" or "*bmw*" patterns work too. - Fix `actor.set_transform()` broken for attached actors. - Fix None is a reserved keyword in Python 3 rename `carla.ColorConverter.None` to `carla.ColorConverter.Raw`. - Workaround for setup.py to link against libcarla_client again (Linux only) - Fix leaking objects in simulation when despawning a vehicle. Now pawn's controller is destroyed if necessary when destroying an Actor. - Suppress exceptions in destructors. ## Issues that fixes - Fix #13 Collisions are not annotated when vehicle's speed is low. - Fix #35 SplineMeshRepeater loses its collider mesh. - Fix #496 Issues with two-wheeled vehicles. - Fix #572 Set the max distance culling for foliage. - Fix #576 Adjust pedestrian animations. - Fix #577 Adjust vehicle physics. - Fix #649 Filenames too long. - Fix #692 Overflow on platform time-stamp. - Fix #698 Compiling for Python 3. - Fix #749 Allow controlling the weather from the client-side. - Fix #822 Allow disabling actor physics. - Fix #857 Set transform of actor attached to another one should be relative. ## Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Ubuntu 16.04 * **Python version(s):** 2.7 and 3.5 * **Unreal Engine version(s):** 4.19 ## Possible Drawbacks Definitively. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/915)

Title: Append to Travis build logs instead of over writing
Body: #### Description The Travis build logs were being overwritten at each make step. If any step failed only the current step's output is shown (upto 2000 lines). Which is okay assuming the failure is only with the current step but often it is useful to have the full build log (or at least the last 2000 lines from the combined log). This PR simply appends the stdout & stderr from all the make steps into `build.log` instead of over-writing to provide verbose build error logs. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/957)

Title: A few fixes for 0 9 3
Body: #### Description A collection of changes that fix a few critical things * Includes changes of #1150 but fixes a bug that became apparent after those changes. The streams were not kept alive when sending data async that caused crashes after destroying sensors. Now I made sure the FAsyncDataStream is safe to be called both sync (game-thread) and async. * Improved simulator fatal error handling now uses UE4 fatal error system. E.g. better output when the address is already in use (#1111). * Fixed lost error messages in client-side now when a request fails it reports the reason (#1095 #1111). * Fixed crash when an actor was destroyed but not deregistered e.g. falling out of world bounds (#1168). * Exceptions have been removed from LibCarla server pipeline now we compile with `-fno-exceptions`. Dependencies have been updated to avoid exception all but rpclib this one still uses exceptions. This may gives us problems but removing exceptions would require to modify the library so for now we are postponing this. * Replaced all "throw" occurrences by "carla::throw_exception" now all the exceptions including in Boost library are re-routed through "carla::throw_exception". * Reduced compilation time of LibCarla.server. * Split unit test since we need to compile both with and without exceptions divided into server client or common. * Added adaptors to serialize boost::variant and boost::optional with MsgPack. This improves significantly serialized size of DebugShapes. We could use it too for rpc::Actor though not implemented here. * Added a new template class Response every rpc call to the simulator is now replied with a Response. Responses may contain a value or an error string. * Added `UCarlaStatic` for a collection of util static methods for UE4 code and blueprints. #### Fixes - Fixes #1119. - Fixes #1168. - Fixes #1095. #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Ubuntu 16.04 * **Python version(s):** 2.7 and 3.5 * **Unreal Engine version(s):** 4.21 #### Possible Drawbacks Core functionality has been modified careful testing is needed. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/1184)

Title: Features for 0 9 4
Body: I'm sorry I did it again. To avoid merge conflicts I rebased everything into a single PR. #### Changing map at runtime from client-side The following API functions were added to the Client object - `get_available_maps()` Retrieves a list with the paths of all the maps available to the simulator (dynamically finds all the maps available at runtime) thanks to @dnovillo-CVC. - `load_map(map_name)` Loads the map given this resets the whole simulation to start anew. `map_name` can be either a full path or the name of a city in our maps folder i.e. "Town02" is equivalent to "/Game/Carla/Maps/Town02". Returns the newly load world. - `reload_map()` Reloads the current map (equivalent to `load_map("")`). ```py world = client.load_world('Town05') ``` Bear in mind that any reference to an actor belonging to the previous world will be invalidated. Trying to operate with an actor from an old world results in an exception. Callbacks added to `world.on_tick(...)` are removed. #### Synchronous mode Synchronous mode is back! when synchronous mode is enabled the simulator waits every update until a client gives the order to continue. Synchronous mode can be enabled at any time via world settings (see below). Once enabled the client is responsible of calling ```py client.tick() ``` every time is ready to continue with the next simulation update. In order to add this I had have to enforce an strict "tick order" to all the relevant Carla actors. Things happen like this now 1. Send world tick (transforms velocities etc.) used by wait_for_tick 2. Update UE4 actors (autopilot traffic lights etc.) 3. Parse client requests 4. If sync-mode and client did not tick repeat 3. I have worked hard to avoid any kind of dead-lock between client and server but I wouldn't be surprised if there are still some situations resulting in total block. Please report if you find one of those! #### Batch commands Finally we have a way of sending commands in batch. This is not only more efficient but also allows to apply a command to every actor in the same tick e.g. sending the control to every NPC vehicle or why not making all the cars jump at the same instant. ```py actors = [x for x in world.world.get_actors() if x.id != world.player.id] client.apply_batch([carla.command.ApplyVelocity(x.id carla.Vector3D(z=5)) for x in actors]) batch = [carla.command.SetAutopilot(x.id False) for x in actors] batch += [carla.command.ApplyVehicleControl(x.id carla.VehicleControl(throttle=1.0)) for x in actors] client.apply_batch(batch) ``` The following batch commands are available (they're under `carla.command` module) * `DestroyActor(actor_id)` * `ApplyVehicleControl(actor_id `control)` * `ApplyWalkerControl(actor_id `control)` * `ApplyTransform(actor_id `transform)` * `ApplyVelocity(actor_id `velocity)` * `ApplyAngularVelocity(actor_id `angular_velocity)` * `ApplyImpulse(actor_id `impulse)` * `SetSimulatePhysics(actor_id `enabled)` * `SetAutopilot(actor_id `enabled)` #### World settings Added world settings this settings can be changed at any time and have effect immediately. At this point only two settings are available * `carla.WorldSettings` - `synchronous_mode` - `no_rendering_mode` and use them like this ```py settings = world.get_settings() settings.no_rendering_mode = True world.apply_settings(settings) ``` #### Support for random streaming port Now it is possible to control the secondary port used for streaming the sensor data. So far this port was always set to RPC port + 1 now it is possible to specify this port and even let the OS to chose a random available port for you by settings it to 0. The client will automatically connect as this info is sent through the RPC port. These port are configured when launching the simulator ``` ./CarlaUE4.sh -carla-rpc-port=2000 -carla-streaming-port=0 ``` #### Non-sticky vehicle control I added an attribute to vehicle blueprints to specify whether the applied control is "sticky". By default is set to "True" i.e. the behaviour we always had. ```py bp.set_attribute("sticky_control" "False") ``` When "sticky_control" is "False" the control is reset every frame to its default (throttle=0 steer=0 brake=0). So unless the client sends a control message the vehicle will eventually stop. In the future we would like to add more realistic relaxation curves for this control but we wanted to release this already so users can start experimenting with it and hopefully give some feedback on how to improve it. ## Fixes - #1258 Ensure tick order. - #1244 Synchronous mode. - #1272 Allow changing map from client-side. - #784 Control over multiple vehicles in batch mode. - Fixed a few synchronization issues that appeared once restarting an episode was possible. - Reduced overhead of many RPC calls by sending only actor IDs (instead of serializing all the actor attributes every time). - Added priority system for vehicle control input. - Make episodes have a random unique id to avoid collisions between runs. - Finally got rid of Example.CarlaSettings.ini you can still use it but it's no longer necessary. - Also updated the link to the content with latest fixes from art. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/1322)

Title: Reworked OpenDrive parser
Body: #### Description Since we had a limited OpenDrive parsing recently appeared the need to expand it. - Now the whole OpenDrive is parsed and not only what we initially need. - The internal structure is more similar to OpenDrive itself so it is more expandable and queries are easy. #### Python API Changes Our idea always is not to change how the Python API is used once we add new functionalities but in this case this was not possible. ###### Additions: * ~~**carla.Waypoint.id**: Unique identifier for a Waypoint based on the hash of it's `road_id` `section_id` `lane_id` and `s`.~~ (already in master added section_id) * **carla.Waypoint.section_id**: Refers to OpenDrive's [`laneSection`](http://opendrive.org/docs/OpenDRIVEFormatSpecRev1.4H.pdf#page=21) number used as an id. * ~~**carla.Waypoint.s**: The [`s`](http://opendrive.org/docs/OpenDRIVEFormatSpecRev1.4H.pdf#page=15) parameter of OpenDrive it defines the position along the reference line measured in meters from the beginning of the track calculated in the XY-plane.~~ (already in master) * **carla.LaneType**: Define the type of lane. The most common are _NONE_ _Driving_ _Shoulder_ _Sidewalk_ _Bidirectional_ and _Parking_ although OpenDrive use [more of them](http://opendrive.org/docs/OpenDRIVEFormatSpecRev1.4H.pdf#page=93). These enums can be used as flags for queries. * **_Extended_ carla.LaneMarking**: + **type** Defines the [types](http://opendrive.org/docs/OpenDRIVEFormatSpecRev1.4H.pdf#page=92). + **color**: Defines the [color](http://opendrive.org/docs/OpenDRIVEFormatSpecRev1.4H.pdf#page=92). + **lane_change** contains the lane change information of a single road mark indicating from which side of it you are allowed to cross. + **width**: Width of the road mark. * **carla.Waypoint.right_lane_marking** / **carla.Waypoint.left_lane_marking**: Returns a `carla.LaneMarking` for the right or left Waypoint's lane marking. ###### Changes: * **carla.LaneMarking** is not an enum anymore but an object. The enum is now **carla.LaneMarking.type**. * **carla.Waypoint.lane_type** doesn't work with strings anymore now uses an enum `carla.LaneType`. * **carla.Map.get_waypoint(location project_to_road=True lane_type=carla.LaneType.Driving)**: you can use it like before and will work as expected but now accepts a `carla.LaneType` that can be used as a flag to filter lane types for instance: `carla.Map.get_waypoint(location project_to_road=True lane_type=(carla.LaneType.Driving | carla.LaneType.Sidewalk)` will search for the nearest waypoint on the center of a _Driving_ or _Sidewalk_ lane. ###### More * Allow "carla.Map" object to be constructed from a XODR file (now it can be constructed without connecting to the simulator). * New functionality FileSystem::ListFolder. * Const and non-const versions of iterator::make_map_{values keys}_iterator now they also work on references instead of copies. * Add additional repo for testing resources (OpenDrive files) automatically downloaded when running unit tests. #### To Do - [x] Update CHANGELOG - [x] Update python_api.md - [x] Fix LaneCrossingCalculator - [x] ~~Test OpenDriveActor~~ (done in a different branch) - [x] Fix uses of `lane_type == 'driving'` (replace with `lane_type == carla.LaneType.Driving`) - [x] Fix uses of `waypoint.next(precision)[0]` --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/1451)

Title: Compile with extra warnings
Body: #### Description After noticing there were a lot of possible bugs specially related to narrowing conversions I switched on a lot more warnings for compiling LibCarla - `-Werror -Wall -Wextra -Wpedantic -Wdeprecated -Wshadow -Wuninitialized -Wunreachable-code -Wpessimizing-move -Wold-style-cast -Wnull-dereference -Wduplicate-enum -Wnon-virtual-dtor -Wheader-hygiene -Wconversion -Wfloat-overflow-conversion` To do so I had to fix a lot of things - Included external libraries (boost rpc) as system to suppress warnings in those headers. - Fixed all the warnings that popped up specially related to `-Wconversion`. - Disallowed implicit conversions between Vector3D/FVector and Vector2D/FVector2D this uncovered a bug in the VehiclePhysicsControl (center of mass in centimeters). - Added more levels of assertions (effectively throwing exceptions in release) and use them in some parts of the code. #### Possible Drawbacks Some of the warnings can be annoying to developers some times but I believe this can ensure that a minimum quality is met and can avoid some bugs. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/1571)

Title: Upgrade to Unreal Engine 4 22

Title: Manishthani load props definition
Body: #### Description Users can now register their own props with `.fbx` format and make these props available through the existing Carla Blueprint Library API. Also these props can be spawned maintaining compatibility with semantic segmentation tags. To do so the following steps should be done: 1) Create a folder called `FBXImporter` inside Carla root folder 2) Place all your props in `.fbx` format inside `FBXImporter` folder. 3) Inside `FBXImporter` folder create a JSON File with the name of your package and with extension `.PropRegistry.json`. For example `YourPackageName.PropRegistry.json` 4) Store in that file a JSON Array called `definitions` which will contain JSON Objects with relevant information for importing a prop such as: - name: The name of your prop this name is the one that will be registered in the Carla Blueprint Library - source: The path to your `.fbx` file. - size: The size of your prop. String Values can be: `tiny` `small` `medium` `big` and `huge` - tag: The semantic segmentation tag. An example of `.PropRegistry.json` file would be: ```json { "definitions": [ { "name": "Prop01" "size": "medium" "source": "SM_Prop_1.fbx" "tag": "Pole" } { "name": "Prop02" "size": "medium" "source": "SM_Prop_2.fbx" "tag": "Roads" } ] } ``` 5) Run the script `import_fbx.py` located inside the carla `Util` folder. Once the script has finished each prop located in the `FBXImporter` will be available inside Carla Content in Unreal in path: `Content/YourPackageName/Static/PropTag/PropName/PropSource` and also will be included in the Carla Blueprint Library so they can be queried and spawned as well. Fixes # #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Ubuntu 16.04LTS * **Python version(s):** 2.7.12 and 3.5.4 * **Unreal Engine version(s):** 4.21 #### Possible Drawbacks --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/1603)

Title: Set vulkan as default graphics api for linux Changed make files to allow user to start
Body: …unreal editor with vulkan or opengl #### Description Since Unreal 4.21 Unreal picks Vulkan instead of OpenGL as the default graphics API for Linux. If Vulkan is not installed on the user's system or the graphics driver or gpu does not support it then Unreal will detect this automatically and use OpenGl 4.5 instead. Vulkan is a lower level graphics API and performs better than OpenGL. Users who enable it should see a significant increase in fps when running the simulator. To use Vulkan install on your system along with latest graphics driver using the following tutorial: https://linuxconfig.org/install-and-test-vulkan-on-linux Currently 415 is the latest driver so replace 396 with 415. vulkaninfo | less command can be used to check that vulkan is working on your system. You should be able to see details about your graphics card. This PR updates the Unreal project settings to add Vulkan to the list of RHIs. Unreal should pick Vulkan instead of OpenGL by default once vulkan is installed on your system. Note: This change only effects Linux. DirectX 11/12 is used on Windows and Unreal does not support Vulkan on Windows currently. #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Ubuntu 16.04 * **Python version(s):** irrelevant * **Unreal Engine version(s):** 4.22.1 * **GPUs:** GTX 1080 and RTX 2070 #### Possible Drawbacks GPUs below NVidia 900 series may be better off using OpenGL. If this is the case OpenGL can be enabled when launching the unreal editor with the CARLA make script by doing the following: make launch ARGS=--use-opengl --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/1639)

Title: Allow setting fixed time step at runtime and package in shipping mode
Body: #### Description Found a way for setting the fixed time step mode at runtime I added it to `carla.WorldSettings` as `fixed_delta_seconds`. If `fixed_delta_seconds` is `None` means the simulator is running at variable time step else specifies the delta time in seconds of each time step (1/FPS). Since we can now change this from the client-side we can compile the release version in "Shipping" mode which removes a lot of debug information and command-line options but runs significantly faster. I have also created a convenient Python script to change maps and configure the simulator to compensate the lack of command-line options. Fixes #1852. #### Drawbacks * We lose a lot of useful debug information when running a release. * It's not possible to specify the map when launching the simulator. * It's not possible to set a fixed time step (`-benchmark -fps=X`) when launching the simulator. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/1857)

Title: Extended RGB sensor
Body: #### Description I've added more control over the RGB camera sensor so you can work with them as a real camera. All the currently available RGB camera settings can be modified like this: ```py # Sensor camera_bp.set_attribute('sensor_tick' str(0.0)) # Image camera_bp.set_attribute('image_size_x' str(800)) camera_bp.set_attribute('image_size_y' str(600)) camera_bp.set_attribute('gamma' str(2.2)) # Camera (used for manual exposure and depth of field) camera_bp.set_attribute('fov' str(90.0)) camera_bp.set_attribute('shutter_speed' str(60.0)) camera_bp.set_attribute('iso' str(1200.0)) camera_bp.set_attribute('fstop' str(1.4)) # Aperture is 1.0 / fstop camera_bp.set_attribute('min_fstop' str(1.2)) # Maximum Aperture camera_bp.set_attribute('blade_count' str(5)) # Exposure ("manual" by default) camera_bp.set_attribute('exposure_mode' str('manual')) camera_bp.set_attribute('exposure_compensation' str(3.0)) # Exposure - histogram specific (used when "exposure_mode" == "histogram") camera_bp.set_attribute('exposure_min_bright' str(0.1)) camera_bp.set_attribute('exposure_max_bright' str(2.0)) camera_bp.set_attribute('exposure_speed_up' str(3.0)) camera_bp.set_attribute('exposure_speed_down' str(1.0)) camera_bp.set_attribute('calibration_constant' str(16.0)) # Depth of field camera_bp.set_attribute('focal_distance' str(1000.0)) camera_bp.set_attribute('blur_amount' str(1.0)) camera_bp.set_attribute('blur_radius' str(0.0)) # Motion Blur camera_bp.set_attribute('motion_blur_intensity' str(0.45)) camera_bp.set_attribute('motion_blur_max_distortion' str(0.35)) camera_bp.set_attribute('motion_blur_min_object_screen_size' str(0.1)) # Tonemapper camera_bp.set_attribute('slope' str(0.88)) camera_bp.set_attribute('toe' str(0.55)) camera_bp.set_attribute('shoulder' str(0.26)) camera_bp.set_attribute('black_clip' str(0.0)) camera_bp.set_attribute('white_clip' str(0.04)) # Color camera_bp.set_attribute('temp' str(6500.0)) camera_bp.set_attribute('tint' str(0.0)) # Other camera_bp.set_attribute('enable_postprocess_effects' str(True)) ``` _in this example they all are set to the default value_ More information about these attributes can be found in the UE4 official docs: [Automatic Exposure](https://docs.unrealengine.com/en-US/Engine/Rendering/PostProcessEffects/AutomaticExposure/index.html) [Cinematic DOF Methods](https://docs.unrealengine.com/en-US/Engine/Rendering/PostProcessEffects/DepthOfField/CinematicDOFMethods/index.html) [Color Grading](https://docs.unrealengine.com/en-US/Engine/Rendering/PostProcessEffects/ColorGrading/index.html) #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Ubuntu 16.04 * **Python version(s):** 2 & 3 * **Unreal Engine version(s):** 4.22.2 #### Possible Drawbacks I've exposed everything as it is in UE4. The final RGB output can be different than expected because different settings going on in the weather system is done un UE4 blueprints. This will be investigated in the future. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/1950)

Title: Standalone OpenDRIVE support
Body: #### Description Basically added the functionality to create a new map in the server from raw OpenDRIVE data even remotely from the client. ![town01](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15848712/74855660-468f5680-5341-11ea-8222-1e406086e87b.png) _Example using the OpenDRIVE file from Town01_ - **C++** - Added `carla::geom::Mesh` a minimal mesh data container validator and exporter. - Added export support for [Wavefront `.obj` file](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wavefront_.obj_file). This also allows the Recast library to consume these files and generate the binaries for our pedestrians to walk on the generated sidewalks. - Added `carla::road::Map::GenerateGeometry(double distance)` that builds a mesh based on OpenDRIVE data. The sidewalks are generated with some height above the roads. - Created the Unreal's AActor `OpenDriveGenerator` that uses the generated mesh to build an Unreals procedural mesh with collisions on it so the cars can drive over them. - **PythonAPI** - Added `calra.client.generate_opendrive_world(opendrive)` that loads a map with custom OpenDRIVE basic physical topology. This works similarly to client.load_map(map_name) but it expects the OpenDRIVE data as `string`. - **Content** - Added a new map `Content/Maps/OpenDriveMap.umap` that hosts those maps generated from raw OpenDRIVE. #### How to test Updated the `PythonAPI/util/config.py` with the argument `--xodr-path` (or `-x`) that expects a path to an OpenDRIVE (.xodr) file and loads this new custom map. #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Ubuntu 18.04 * **Python version(s):** 2 & 3 * **Unreal Engine version(s):** 4.22 #### Possible Drawbacks The roads can contain some gaps (especially on junctions) since OpenDRIVE does not define the ground itself but the drivable zones of it. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/2491)

Title: Sumo traffic lights integration
Body: #### Description This PR adds several improvements regarding sumo co-simulation. 1. Synchronization of traffic lights. This synchronization can be split into two different functionalities: * The `netconvert_carla.py` script (inside the `util` folder) that generates sumo nets based on opendrive files. Internally it uses netconvert to generate the net and inserts manually the traffic light landmarks retrieved from the opendrive. This is done to reduce differences with the traffic lights spwaned in carla. Example of usage: ```sh python netconvert_carla.py --output Test.net.xml ``` * The actual synchronization of traffic lights. The user is able to select which simulator has the control over the traffic lights. Example of usage: ```sh python run_synchronization.py -c examples/TestTLS.sumocfg --tls-manager carla. ``` The `tls-manager` argument may take the following values: `sumo` `carla` `none` The synchronization of traffic lights only works with opendrive files with signals. Therefore this feature is not available for the current towns of carla. 2. The script `spawn_npc_sumo.py` that imitates the functionality of the traditional `spawn_npc.py` but using sumo instead of traffic manager. This script is only available for Town01 04 05. #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Ubuntu 18.04 * **Python version(s):** 3.6.9 2.7.17 * **Unreal Engine version(s):** 4.24 #### Possible Drawbacks --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/2714)

Title: Better build script
Body: #### Description I have inserted more checks in the **build.sh** and **build.bat** scripts that generates the binary file for the pedestrians navigation. Also to run the FBX2OBJ we need in the same folder the shared libraries from Autodesk FBX SDK (**libfbxsdk.so** or **libfbxsdk.dll**) - if .obj is given it will be processed at the end for the Recast calculation - if .xodr is given then a script will extract all the zones that are crosswalks and they will be added as meshes (planes) to the .obj (if exist) or the .obj will be created with them. #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Ubuntu 16 18 and Windows 10 * **Python version(s):** 2.7 and 3.7 * **Unreal Engine version(s):** UE 4.24 #### Possible Drawbacks To generate the binary file from the FBX we need to install Autodesk FBX SDK and compile the given source for FBX2OBJ and then place the .SO or .DLL from Autodesk to the folder **Carla/Util/DockerUtils/dist/**. To avoid this step we need to provide the FBX as an OBJ file using for example the Carla Exporter. We can not do that automatically because of the Autodesk license that the user needs to agree. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/2774)

Title: Exposed car lights to client
Body: #### Description Now the vehicle lights can be turned on and off from the client-side. `manual_control.py` has been updated to allow this too so feel free to experiment with it. Open the help panel (`H` key) for more information. You will need the latest art repo to work with cars that have lights implemented. Right now they are: Tesla **Model3** **Cybertruck** (yup :wink:) and the Volkswagen **T3** To control them from the client we exposed the `VehicleLightState` that is an enum that works as a flag container. The values are: - Position - LowBeam - HighBeam - Brake - RightBlinker - LeftBlinker - Reverse - Fog - Interior - Special1 - Special2 _The special ones are reserved to car specific lights (like ambulance sirens)_ An example opening the position light and low beam light from some vehicle: ```py # Decide which ones do we want to open adding these flags lights_to_open = carla.VehicleLightState( carla.VehicleLightState.Position | carla.VehicleLightState.LowBeam) # Set the state of the car lights to match the flag we created vehicle.set_light_state(lights_to_open) ``` #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Ubuntu 18.04 * **Python version(s):** 3.6 * **Unreal Engine version(s):** 4.22 #### Possible Drawbacks You can experiment with performance issues when enabling big amount of lights. This is more an Unreal/Art issue but should be taken into consideration while using the API. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/2414)

Title: Fix windows script to find UE4 directory
Body: #### Description In Windows build there was a discrepancy on how to get the Unreal Engine directory so we now use two methods together: - First it tries to use the environment variable **UE4_ROOT**. If that variable is defined then we use it. - If the UE4_ROOT is not defined then we search on the windows registry for all keys inside: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\EpicGames\Unreal Engine\ the result could be: 4.21 4.22 4.23 4.24 then we use always the last one following the order on the registry so probably the last installed version of UE will be the one to use. We get the **InstalledDirectory** of that version and we can continue. If all these methods fail the we can not make the windows build. Title: Building Carla on Ubuntu 20 04 LTS
Body: #### Description Most of the instructions for building Carla on Ubuntu 18.04 works for 20.04 as well except for dropping Python 2.7 related dependencies. Like so: ``` sudo apt-get install build-essential clang-8 lld-8 g++-7 cmake ninja-build libvulkan1 python3 python3-pip python3-dev libpng-dev libtiff5-dev libjpeg-dev tzdata sed curl unzip autoconf libtool rsync libxml2-dev && pip3 install --user setuptools ``` Build scripts are also modified to remove Python 2.7 targets. One could manually install Python 2.7 and retain support for it but it's probably better to just let go of it. P.S. No need to add Xenial or Bionic deb repository which is the first command in the build instructions in the [docs](https://carla.readthedocs.io/en/latest/build_linux/) i.e ``` sudo apt-get update && sudo apt-get install wget software-properties-common && sudo add-apt-repository ppa:ubuntu-toolchain-r/test && wget -O - https://apt.llvm.org/llvm-snapshot.gpg.key|sudo apt-key add - && sudo apt-add-repository "deb http://apt.llvm.org/xenial/ llvm-toolchain-xenial-8 main" && sudo apt-get update ``` I was able to build Carla on Ubuntu 20.04 with only Focal Fossa deb repository. #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Ubuntu 20.04 * **Python version(s):** 3.8 * **Unreal Engine version(s):** 4.24 #### Possible Drawbacks * To run scripts that use pygame need to use pygame developent version 2.0.0.dev6 as 1.9.6 can't be installed from pip on Python 3.8. ``` pip3 install pygame==2.0.0.dev6 ``` --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/2787)

Title: Initial chhrono implementation
Body: #### Description This PR brings an initial implementation of the CHRONO physics engine for vehicles (http://projectchrono.org/) to CARLA. For vehicles it adds a new function `enable_chrono_physics(max_substeps max_substep_delta_time)` which hands the physics simulation of the vehicle to CHRONO. The implementation is done in `ChronoMovementComponent.h` and `ChronoMovementComponent.cpp`. The build system has been changed to add the CHRONO library to be compiled and included in CARLA. CHRONO is added as an optional module in order to include it in your project you need to add the argument "--chrono" to the `make XXX` commands. In addition CHRONO requires RTTI enabled which requires a small modification to the Unreal Engine: in the file `Engine\Source\Programs\UnrealBuildTool\Configuration\TargetRules.cs` the line `public bool bForceEnableRTTI = false;` needs to chenge to `public bool bForceEnableRTTI = true;`. #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Ubuntu 18 Windows * **Python version(s):** 3 * **Unreal Engine version(s):** 4.24 #### Possible Drawbacks For Linux without the chrono module CARLA is compatible with RTTI on and off but this is not the case for Windows. If RTTI is on then the CHRONO flag should be used as well. This will change once we enable RTTI always. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/3857)

Title: CARLA uses the old and new RoadRunner nomenclature
Body: #### Description RoadRunner last release has changed the way they name assets for the road. Before it was starting by **Road_** but in last version they changed to plural word **Roads_**. That broke our nomenclature for the semantic segmentation and also pedestrian navigation that are based on the name of the asset to identify different parts of a road (sidewalks crosswalks markings...). Now CARLA can use **Road_** and also **Roads_** as part of the nomenclature. All of these are valid now: - Road_Road - Roads_Road - Road_Marking - Roads_Marking - Road_Curb - Roads_Curb - Road_Gutter - Roads_Gutter - Road_Sidewalk - Roads_Sidewalk - Road_Crosswalk - Roads_Crosswalk - Road_Grass - Roads_Grass Also when a FBX amp was imported the name of the FBX was added as a prefix of the name of all assets. We were removing that name but only until the first **_** that was found. That was problematic if the name of the FBX had some **_** already because part of the FBX name was not removed properly. Now that has been fixed and the FBX name can have any **_**. #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Windows * **Python version(s):** 3.7 * **Unreal Engine version(s):** 4.24 #### Possible Drawbacks We need to update documentation in a new PR --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/3840)

Title: Chrono JSON vehicle definition
Body: #### Description This PR adds the capability to define chrono vehicles with JSON files that can be set from the python side. API changes: `actor.enable_chrono_physics(max_substeps max_substep_delta_time vehicle_json powetrain_json tire_json base_json_path)` - **max_substeps**: max number of chrono substeps - **max_substep_delta_time**: max size of substep - **vehicle_json**: relative path to vehicle json file with respect to `base_json_path` (e.g.: `hmmwv/vehicle/HMMWV_Vehicle.json`) - **powetrain_json**: relative path to powertrain json file with respect to `base_json_path` (e.g.: `hmmwv/powertrain/HMMWV_ShaftsPowertrain.json`) - **tire_json**: relative path to tire json file with respect to `base_json_path` (e.g.: `hmmwv/tire/HMMWV_Pac02Tire.json`) - **base_json_path**: path to `chrono/data/vehicle` folder (e.g.: `/home/user/carla/Build/chrono-install/share/chrono/data/vehicle/`) (final `/` character is required) Reminder: in order to activate chrono the make commands need to include the `ARGS="--chrono"`. #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Ubuntu 18.04 Windows * **Python version(s):** 3 * **Unreal Engine version(s):** 4.24 #### Possible Drawbacks Invalid JSON files or paths will cause a crash in the UE4 side. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/3928)

Title: Added PROJ functionality to OpenStreetMaps conversion to OpenDRIVE
Body: #### Description This PR adds the PROJ library as a dependency for CARLA to enable better projection capabilities for OpenStreetMaps conversion to OpenDRIVE (OSM2ODR). **API additions** `Osm2OdrSettings.proj_string (string)` The user can specify a PROJ.4 string to set the projection parameters. Example: `settings.proj_string = "+proj=tmerc +lat_0=0 +lon_0=0"`. `Osm2OdrSettings.center_map (bool)` Enables centering of the map. This flag disables georeference in OpenDRIVE as the origin of the map does not match latitude and longitude defined in the `proj_string`. Extra Stuff: speed up the `make PythonAPI` command and disable RTTI checks in the Boost library. #### Fixes #3009 #3686 #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Ubuntu 18.04 Windows * **Python version(s):** 3 * **Unreal Engine version(s):** 4.24 --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/3901)

Title: New import process to cook large maps divided in tiles
Body: #### Description Now we can import large maps in tiles resulting in a individual .umap per tile. As before if you don't specify a .json file when importing one is created automatically. A sample one is like this: > { > "maps": [ > { > "name": "testmap" > "xodr": "./testmap.xodr" > "use_carla_materials": true > "tiles": [ > "./testmap_Tile_0_0.fbx" > "./testmap_Tile_0_1.fbx" > "./testmap_Tile_1_0.fbx" > "./testmap_Tile_1_1.fbx" > ] > } > ] > "props": [] > } For the automatic generation of .json to work we need to be sure that the tile have this nomenclature ..._Tile_i_j... the _i_ and _j_ are the index of the tile starting at (0 0). The import process will end as soon as one tile is not found. When a map is in tiles then the **tiles** keyword are in use with the list of all the tiles in .fbx form. If the map is in single mode then we use the **source** keyword with the single .fbx. for the map. The .umap tiles are intended to be used as map containers so there is no sky light on those maps or any other information. Just meshes. Other than the map each tile will have its own .bin file for the pedestrian navigation. The .xodr is a single one that is for the whole map like in single maps. #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Ubuntu / Windows * **Python version(s):** 3.7 * **Unreal Engine version(s):** UE 4.26 #### Possible Drawbacks We need more code to manage the large map tiles so this PR is only for the cooking process. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/4094)

Title: Fixes nullptr bug in CarlaRecorder AddCollision
Body: #### Description Bugfix for a segmentation fault that happens in the server when a vehicle collides with an environment object when the recording is in progress. How to reproduce the bug: 1. start the manual_control 2. start recording (ctrl+R) 3. make a collision with an environment object (a flower a fountain ...). This should cause the server to trigger a segmentation fault in ACarlaRecorder::AddCollision. The segmentation fault is triggered in ACarlaRecorder::AddCollision since one of the colliding objects is not a registered Carla actor but no check is done on the pointer returned by the Episode->GetActorRegistry().FindCarlaActor() method. The submitted patch does these things: 1. In ACarlaRecorder::AddCollision an additional check is performed to ensure that each colliding actor is a registered Carla actor otherwise a non-valid id (-1) is set in the Collision.DatabaseId* field written in the recording file. 2. when the CarlaRecorderQuery::QueryCollisions reads back the recording file the code checks if the Collision.DatabaseId* are valid Carla actor ids otherwise sets the actor type to 'o' ('other' actor). Checklist: - [x] Your branch is up-to-date with the `dev` branch and tested with latest changes - [x] Extended the README / documentation if necessary - [x] Code compiles correctly - [ ] All tests passing with `make check` (only Linux) -> All 48 tests passes. Currently the dev branch does not pass all the tests with make change on my system but this is not related to this pull request. I have tested the submitted code with my scripts to ensure that the bug is fixed and the client.show_recorder_collisions() works correctly. - [x] If relevant update CHANGELOG.md with your changes #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Linux Ubuntu 20.04 * **Python version(s):** 3.7 * **Unreal Engine version(s):** 4.26 #### Possible Drawbacks The code is a bugfix preventing the server to crash. However a different solution could be considered: instead of writing the DatabaseId* in the .rec file (which assumes that only registered Carla actors may collide which is not true) the server could write the blueprint id and search if the id correspond to a carla actor in the CarlaRecorderQuery::QueryCollisions method. This however would break the backward compatibility with the .rec file format. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/4549)
